title: The Principle of 'Defense in Depth'
note: This section introduces the core strategy of network security: Defense in Depth. It explains this concept as a layered approach to security, where multiple, redundant defensive measures are put in place. If one layer fails, another layer is already in place to thwart an attack.

title: Network Reconnaissance: Footprinting and Scanning
note: This lesson explains the first phase of most network attacks: reconnaissance. It covers 'footprinting' (passively gathering information about a target network) and 'scanning' (actively probing the network to discover live hosts, open ports, and running services). The `nmap` tool is introduced.

title: Firewalls: The First Line of Defense
note: This section introduces the firewall as a fundamental network security device. It acts as a barrier between a trusted internal network and an untrusted external network (like the Internet), controlling incoming and outgoing network traffic based on a set of security rules.

title: Types of Firewalls: Packet-Filtering and Stateful
note: This lesson compares two primary types of firewalls. A simple Packet-Filtering firewall inspects packets individually and makes decisions based on IP addresses and ports. A more advanced Stateful firewall keeps track of the state of network connections and makes decisions based on the context of the traffic.

title: Next-Generation Firewalls (NGFW) and UTM
note: This section covers the evolution of firewalls. A Next-Generation Firewall (NGFW) combines traditional firewall capabilities with more advanced features like application awareness and an integrated Intrusion Prevention System (IPS). Unified Threat Management (UTM) devices bundle even more security functions into a single appliance.

title: Intrusion Detection and Prevention Systems (IDS/IPS)
note: This lesson introduces IDS and IPS as systems that monitor network traffic for malicious activity. An Intrusion Detection System (IDS) is a passive device that detects and alerts on potential threats. An Intrusion Prevention System (IPS) is an active device that can also take action to block the threat.

title: IDS/IPS: Signature-Based vs. Anomaly-Based Detection
note: This section explains the two main methods used by IDS/IPS. Signature-based detection works like antivirus software, looking for known patterns of malicious traffic. Anomaly-based detection builds a model of 'normal' network behavior and flags any deviation from that baseline as potentially malicious.

title: Virtual Private Networks (VPNs)
note: This lesson explains how a VPN creates a secure, private network connection over a public network like the Internet. It works by creating an encrypted 'tunnel' between a user's device and a VPN server, protecting the traffic from eavesdropping and making it appear as if the user is on the VPN server's local network.

title: Securing the Network Layer: IPsec
note: This section covers IPsec, a suite of protocols that provides security at the Network Layer (Layer 3). IPsec can be used to authenticate and encrypt each IP packet in a data stream, providing a very high level of security. It is often used to implement VPNs.

title: Securing the Transport Layer: TLS
note: This lesson introduces Transport Layer Security (TLS), the successor to SSL, as the standard protocol for providing security at the Transport Layer. TLS is what powers HTTPS and is used to encrypt communication for a wide variety of applications, ensuring confidentiality and integrity between two communicating applications.

title: The TLS Handshake
note: This section provides a high-level overview of the TLS handshake process. This is the negotiation between a client and server at the start of a session where they agree on the cryptographic algorithms to be used, exchange a public key via a certificate, and securely generate a shared symmetric key for the rest of the session.

title: Securing the Application Layer: DNSSEC
note: This lesson covers DNSSEC (Domain Name System Security Extensions). It is a suite of specifications for securing the DNS protocol. DNSSEC works by adding cryptographic signatures to DNS records, allowing a client to verify that the IP address it received for a domain name is authentic and has not been tampered with.

title: Wireless Network Security
note: This section focuses on the unique security challenges of wireless networks. It explains the history and weaknesses of the old WEP protocol and details the modern standards, WPA2 and WPA3, which provide strong encryption and authentication for Wi-Fi networks.

title: Wireless Attacks: 'Evil Twin' Hotspots
note: This lesson explains a common wireless attack. An 'Evil Twin' is a fraudulent Wi-Fi access point that appears to be a legitimate one, but is actually set up by an attacker to eavesdrop on wireless communications. The attacker can then launch man-in-the-middle attacks to steal user credentials.

title: Denial-of-Service (DoS) Attacks
note: This section defines a DoS attack as an attempt to make a machine or network resource unavailable to its intended users. It explains how this can be done by flooding the target with traffic (a volumetric attack) or by exploiting a specific vulnerability in a protocol or application.

title: Distributed Denial-of-Service (DDoS) Attacks
note: This lesson explains that a DDoS attack is a DoS attack that originates from many different sources (often a 'botnet' of compromised computers). The distributed nature of the attack makes it much harder to block than a simple DoS attack from a single source.

title: DDoS Mitigation Techniques
note: This section provides an overview of techniques used to defend against DDoS attacks. These include rate limiting, blackholing (dropping all traffic to a target), and using specialized cloud-based DDoS mitigation services that can absorb and filter out massive amounts of malicious traffic.

title: Network Monitoring with Wireshark
note: This lesson introduces Wireshark as a powerful, free, and open-source packet analyzer. It is used for network troubleshooting, analysis, and protocol development. It allows you to capture network traffic and inspect the contents of individual packets in detail.

title: Security Information and Event Management (SIEM)
note: This section introduces SIEM systems as a tool for providing a holistic view of an organization's security. A SIEM collects log data from various sources (like firewalls, servers, and applications), correlates the events, and generates alerts when it detects potentially malicious activity.

title: The Zero Trust Security Model
note: This final lesson looks at a modern approach to network security. The Zero Trust model is based on the principle of 'never trust, always verify'. It assumes that the internal network is just as hostile as the external internet and requires strict identity verification for every person and device trying to access resources on the network, regardless of their location.
